issues.title: section 3.2.1
issues.author: acbegen
issues.body:
It says: 
      TCP Slow-start when restarting after idle requires multiple RTTs
      to re-establish a throughput at the network's available capacity.
      On high-RTT paths or with small enough segments, this can produce
      a falsely low application-visible measurement of the available
      network capacity.

Well, TCP slow-start restart happens when TCP stays idle long enough. "Long enough" is a factor for RTT, so I don't think slow-start restart is more likely when RTT is higher. When the segments are small, it is not more likely, either. I think what we are looking for is when the "on" duration is substantially longer than the "off" duration in the HTTP transaction. And that means, when the segment download time is substantially shorter than the inter-request time (typically the segment duration), which implies download speed is far greater than the segment's encoding bitrate. In that case, SSR will likely happen.

comments.author: GrumpyOldTroll
comments.body: Yes, good point, thanks, the main thing is the amount of idle time.  Maybe a reference to RFC 7661 is also in order, as a mitigation for senders who expect this.  Not sure if the default behavior for common server systems should get a mention here as well (and also maybe stuff like linux's net.ipv4.tcp_slow_start_after_idle).

comments.author: acbegen
comments.body: 7661 could be mentioned as a note. I have seen some servers disabling SSR while others leaving it on by default.

issues.title: Low-latency vs. others
issues.author: acbegen
issues.body:
I think this draft deserves a separate section that will explain what streaming is and what latency is. Then a classification of based on the latency requirements is in order. 
1) low latency live (glass-to-glass latency should be < 10s, to compete with broadcast)
2) non-low-latency live (still live but latency can be > 10s)
3) on-demand (where latency is not a concern, but startup delay is)

Then topics like inter-destination (or inter-player) synchronization becomes important. Your dash stream vs. the broadcast or the twitter feed. They need to be more or less close to each other in the time domain as otherwise it will look bad.

comments.author: GrumpyOldTroll
comments.body: +1, this sounds like a valuable section to me.  Especially if there's references for the numbers involved in the requirements.

comments.body: I can take a crack at this as well.

comments.author: agouaillard-cosmo
comments.body: I think you need to make a real-time section (<1s), to separate the technologies that are not http-based nor file-based. We could put there RTMP, RTSP 2.0, WebRTC and globally all kinds of RTP-based streaming techs. There is an emergence of use cases that require that, and teh slides from Justin Uberti during MOPS@IETF 105 about Stadia is a good example. (https://datatracker.ietf.org/meeting/105/materials/minutes-105-mops-00). Some people use "interactive streaming" to refer to it. Stadia is aiming for 150ms latency.

issues.title: E2E encryption
issues.author: acbegen
issues.body:
This should be discussed in the following contexts:
1) Content owners feel more secure when their contents are encrypted at every level (at the transport/http level in addition to the application level, DRM, etc.).
2) E2E encryption is becoming more prevailing as the streaming service providers also do not want to be messed by the network service providers any more.
a) Network service providers should not mess with manifests, requests, media, etc. This is unlawful for many reasons.
b) Network service providers should rather co-operate with the streaming service providers to enhance the user experience as well as better utilize the network resources. See server and network assisted DASH, part 5 of the DASH standard (https://www.iso.org/standard/69079.html)

comments.author: GrumpyOldTroll
comments.body:
I'm not sure the feelings of the content owners can be generalized cleanly, but I agree it might make sense to talk about the security (and privacy) characteristics of the available encryption approaches that can be applied at different layers, as well as the trends in the use of encryption.  That seems like a good point.

I'm a little worried this is a can of worms that might be better as a separate document, because I think it gets quite complicated if we end up trying to explain the security properties, the threat models, and the challenges in guarding against the threat models, and far more so if that pulls us toward touching on anything potentially controversial.

But I agree there's probably something useful to say about encryption with regard to operational considerations for media streaming, and that it can likely be a useful section if we can keep the scope constrained.

comments.author: agouaillard-cosmo
comments.body: I believe there are many resources in terms of e2eme (m => media) that could be listed to give a good overview, without going too much int the details. DRM model for media, as used in conjunction with MPEG-DASH and HLS, and used by the W3C are one (https://www.w3.org/TR/2017/REC-encrypted-media-20170918/), the work of the PERC working group for RTP over UDP/TCP is another one (https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-perc-double-12), QUIC is yet another one that would come naturally to mind first.

comments.author: agouaillard
comments.body:
and recent work on e2ee for media over internet:
IETF Frame Working group, and corresponding first draft:
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/charter-ietf-sframe/

comments.author: SpencerDawkins
comments.body: I'm thinking I should take this one, especially with @agouaillard's suggestions. I'll probably downsize that specifically to streaming media, so leaving RTP-based techniques out (at least for now), but this looks super do-able.

comments.author: agouaillard-cosmo
comments.body:
Hi spencer, 

Note that SFrame, unlike it's predecessor PERC which is RTP specific, has been designed to be Media Transport agnostic as we wanted to be able to use RTP or e.g. QUIC. This design was made consciously, as threat models are always use case specific, and we wanted to extract the media encryption itself, which is common to the video conferencing use case and the streaming use case for example. One hope is that this could be used in conjunction to existing DRM facilities (KMS, ...) to extend DRM (in browsers) to the real-time use case, and also to cover the entire media path and not just the delivery part like DRM does today.

The SFrame draft itself describes only the media encryption, while other documents, for now external to the SFrame working group, describe key exchange with MLS in the video conferencing use case (Cisco), or the RTP use case specifically (Part of AVTCORE scope). It is being designed to be compatible with SVC codecs extension for RTP (AVTCORE), and new proposal for WebRTC's ingest signalling (WISH).

Let me know if you want some help in the matter, if only to point you to ongoing effort within IETF to get the big picture.

comments.author: SpencerDawkins
comments.body:
This will heavily point to the impact on increased end-to-end encryption on network operators. RTCWeb (RFC 8825) has a section on this, as does QUIC Manageability. 

Make sure we describe what happens if manifests are encrypted - operators that lower the offered quality to reduce impact on their networks can't do that any more. Also true for analytics/feedback hijacking. Find and reference a public discussion (Netflix, someone in MOPS may be able to provide this).

comments.author: acbegen
comments.body: @SpencerDawkins check this out: http://library.usc.edu.ph/ACM/SIGSAC%202017/codaspy/p361.pdf

issues.title: Definition of streaming
issues.author: acbegen
issues.body:
I suggest a definition along these lines:
Streaming is transmission of a continuous content from a server to a client and its simultaneous consumption by the client. ("simultaneous" is the key here)
This has two implications:
1) Server transmission rate (loosely or tightly) matches to client consumption rate. That is, no buffer overrun or underrun is desirable/acceptable.
2) Client consumption rate is also limited by real-time constraints as opposed to just bandwidth availability. That is, client cannot fetch the content not available yet.

comments.author: GrumpyOldTroll
comments.body: +1, this sgtm.  But this probably implies a refactor of the intro section and the abstract, to better focus on the relevant use case.

comments.author: acbegen
comments.body: I can take a crack at this.

comments.body: Ali has text for this, will create a PR for the issue.

issues.title: Articulate the sources of constraints on bandwidth at different points of the network
issues.author: GrumpyOldTroll
issues.body:
Pulling the TBD out of the draft text and capturing it here instead.

Suggestion from mic at IETF 106 (Mark Nottingham) in response to call for help on capturing the mismatch between supply and demand of bandwidth with regard to video:
Dive into the different constraints coming from different parts of the network or distribution channels. (regarding questions about how to describe the disconnect between demand vs. capacity, while keeping good archival value.)  "These are big numbers, but the internet has grown over time, and CDN capacities have grown over time.  Is it last mile? Probably not--Is it middle mile?  Maybe that's more interesting.  It it CPU? Is it network cards?  Is it the economics of your peering relationships? Unpicking those bits might help a bit.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4_k340xT2jM&t=13m

comments.author: acbegen
comments.body: For many, poor Wifi is the culprit. For many others, the ISP aggregation links are the culprit during the prime times (since most such links are oversubscribed/oversold). For some, the CDN issues create problems and for rare cases, the origin drowns and everybody gets upset. For certain environments like student dorms, campus networks, libraries, airport cafes, it is just lack of bandwidth for the power users.

issues.title: Applicability of pre-placement and caching
issues.author: GrumpyOldTroll
issues.body:
Pulling the TBD out of the draft text and capturing it here instead.

Suggestion from mic at IETF 106 (Dave Oran + Glenn Deen responding):
Pre-placement for many use cases is useful--distinguish between live vs. cacheable.  "People assume high-demand == live, but not always true" with popular netflix example.  Pre-placement in caches can ameliorate high-bandwidth needs without having to use e.g. multicast.  Explain where it's applicable and not, and what the constraints are.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4_k340xT2jM&t=14m15s

(This probably goes in the caching section as that's written.)

comments.author: GrumpyOldTroll
comments.body: +Glenn's comment: also capture latency constraints as a usability/qos part for live+popular vs. pre-recorded and expected-popular.

comments.author: SpencerDawkins
comments.body:
Some comments here.

- Putting what's in the Google doc "now" (where "now" means something like "five minutes before @squarooticus and @ldaigle Request Publication for the draft") in the draft, so that they match for as long as possible - we can also add a Note to the RFC Editor to ask the authors about any possible updates, because there may be changes to links as late as AUTH48 that should be reflected in the published RFC. The RFC Editor has published "snapshot" RFCs in the past - for example, the IETF Tao was published at https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc4677 - so this isn't unprecedented. 
- Doesn't the IETF already own working group GitHub repos? There's a perfectly lovely Wiki in this repo, at https://github.com/ietf-wg-mops/draft-ietf-mops-streaming-opcons/wiki, and no one has ever touched it. 
- Yeah, people need to see NoteWell when they look at the updated list. We can either say "look at the wiki in this wiki (so people see CONTRIBUTING link)", or "look at the wiki at this link (so we need to include the NoteWell in the wiki, too).

issues.title: Discussion on contention and/or fairness in the network
issues.author: LPardue
issues.body:
Since the intro says 

> This document aims to provide a taxonomy of networking issues as they
   relate to quality of experience in internet video delivery.

I'm a little surprised to not see anything about the effects on video QoE caused by contention in the network, or the role that fairness between other flows and/or protocols plays on video and other applications.

Finally, its been interesting to see how large content providers have reduced streaming bitrates in response to large-scale contention during the COVID pandemic, whether voluntarily or via external pressures. This is especially curious when content is distributed via ABR technologies which should accommodate switching to lower bitrates. (I've heard anecdotal reasoning that the detection of contention is too slow, but unsure if that is really true).

comments.author: acbegen
comments.body:
> Finally, its been interesting to see how large content providers have reduced streaming bitrates in response to large-scale contention during the COVID pandemic, whether voluntarily or via external pressures. This is especially curious when content is distributed via ABR technologies which should accommodate switching to lower bitrates. (I've heard anecdotal reasoning that the detection of contention is too slow, but unsure if that is really true).

One of the more logical explanations of the situation I have I read:
https://newsroom.bt.com/the-facts-about-our-network-and-coronavirus/
EU asking Netflix to drop the bitrates was a total BS IMO.

comments.author: murillo128
comments.body:
It is worth noting that some protocols rely on the transport layer bwe/cc (the ones that are TCP based) while others have to implement their own mechanisms (udp based like QUIC or RTP).

In that regard, I would differentiate the loss based bwe/cc algorithms (TCP, new Reno, bbr) vs the delay based ones (copa).

comments.author: SpencerDawkins

I'm planning to focus a PR for this issue on fairness and contention, but defer to the "Extremely Unpredictable Usage Profiles" section, which we've recently merged into Master, for anything about CoViD-19-related impacts on network performance for streaming media. 

Please let me know if that's not a good plan.

OK, I'm about 10 commits (it seemed like more) into the PR for this issue, and am now thinking that I should divide what is now the "Evolution of Transport Protocols and Transport Protocol  Behaviors" section into a UDP/TCP section that comes before the ABR section, because those are the protocols that people use with ABR today, and a QUIC section (that is actually "evolution") that remains after the ABR section. @GrumpyOldTroll and @acbegen, do you have any thoughts about that?

I'm pretty sure it would allow us to tighten up the discussion of interaction between ABR and transport protocol behavior in the ABR section.

issues.title: Adaptive bitrate at low-latency
issues.author: kixelated
issues.body:
One common problem is building an ABR algorithm for low-latency delivery, especially for client-driven protocols (ex. LL-DASH).

Traditional segmented delivery (HLS) allows segments to be downloaded with unlimited throughput. It's clear that if you can download 2s of media in 1s, then your network can handle double the throughput. Vice-versa, if it takes 3s to download 2s of media, then your network is struggling and you should switch down.

But when video is delivered as it is generated (LL-DASH), it is difficult to determine if your connection can handle a higher bitrate. 2s of media will be delivered in 2s even if your network can support a far higher throughput. The connection is application-limited and not congestion-limited.

I haven't explored the public developments in this space, but it's difficult enough that Twitch has [sponsored an academic challenge](https://blog.twitch.tv/en/2020/01/15/twitch-invites-you-to-take-on-our-acm-mmsys-2020-grand-challenge/). In my opinion, it's why LLHLS opted to use smaller segments instead of streaming segments, at the cost of higher latency.

comments.author: agouaillard
comments.body:
That's a good point.

Groups working on real-time media protocols have historically solved this by (1) removing the need for server-side ABR when dealing with adaptation, and (2) managing the media end-to-end instead of by segments (source -> encoding -> ingest -> transcoding -> chunking -> upload -> delivery ....).

"Simulcast" is exactly the same as ABR but on the source side, removing the need for (and the extra latency cost of) transcoding server side. SVC codecs are one step further, since they achieve the same goal but with a single bitstream and have extra resilience, faster resolution shift, and native capacity for End-to-end encryption (DRM on steroids to protect both content and users) built in.

I wrote a little something for non technical audience a few years back, and I m happy to give tech pointers to peer-reviewed papers and/or specifications if need be:
http://webrtcbydralex.com/index.php/2019/04/06/webrtc-1-0-simulcast-vs-abr/

comments.author: acbegen
comments.body:
> I haven't explored the public developments in this space, but it's difficult enough that Twitch has [sponsored an academic challenge](https://blog.twitch.tv/en/2020/01/15/twitch-invites-you-to-take-on-our-acm-mmsys-2020-grand-challenge/). In my opinion, it's why LLHLS opted to use smaller segments instead of streaming segments, at the cost of higher latency.

LL-HLS uses parts (and these are not smaller segments) just like the chunks DASH-LL uses. However, LL-HLS still has a request/response for each of these parts unlike DASH-LL and that gives them the advantage of measuring the available bw a bit easier. But then, we already have developed ways to measure the available bw accurately in DASH-LL anyway.

Check the LoL+ algorithm we implemented (and also available of dash.js as of v3.2) at: https://github.com/Dash-Industry-Forum/dash.js/wiki/Low-Latency-streaming

You might also find Twitch's evaluation interesting: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rcXFVDotpy4

issues.title: Section 2.1.1 Video bit rates table
issues.author: gitnnelg
issues.body:
Somehow I missed this until now- the issue is the representative bit rates in Table 1 are far too high and do not match the actual bit rate ladders that are being used to stream video in production currently.

Curren in the doc, which I believe is based on old encoding rates is:

Name | Width x Height | Typical | Peak

DVD | 720 x 480 | 1.3 Mbps | 3 Mbps
720p (1K) | 1280 x 720 | 3.6 Mbps | 5 Mbps
1080p (2K) | 1920 x 1080 | 8.1 Mbps | 18 Mbps
2160p (4k) | 3840 x 2160 | 32 Mbps | 70 Mbps

For example - Netflix in a blog (https://netflixtechblog.com/optimized-shot-based-encodes-for-4k-now-streaming-47b516b10bbb)  published in Aug of 2020 argues that high quality video can be done at much lower bitrates for 4K video , but their graphs also show other resolutions. 

In the cited experiments they had 4K video bitrates ranging from 8 Mbps down to 1.7Mbps with an average being 3.2 Mbps. 

Certainly 1080p at 1Mbps is quite commonly seen in the wild.  

Perhaps @acbegen can reach into his academic citations and pull out a better bitrate ladder that represents actual delivery rates being used.

issues.title: Adaptive monitoring/feedback loops considerations
issues.author: gitnnelg
issues.body:
the current draft mentions that TCP has a feedback control mechanism while UDP doesn't etc.  It also mentions ABR but with out much detail on what exactly is going on with ABR.

It may be helpful to the reader to have a section that goes a little bit into the mechanism that are being used at the application level.  while application behavior is often outside of the interest by IETF documents, in this case the application's are making choices and collecting data that are directly connected to network performance, and in turn make changes to the applications use of the network and consequently the video transports impact to the network.     

There are a couple mechanisms  by video applications which could be viewed as essentially seen as application layer network management.    1. ABR - which is lightly mentioned in the current draft,  2. Adaptive encoding, 3. player and edge data collection, coupled with a feedback mechanism to the video server and even the player that cause adaptive change decisions on the data being sent such as systems like Conviva.

Not suggesting a huge section, but something should be included about how application layer monitoring and adaptive decision making by players/servers is a form of network flow/use flow control especially when UDP/QUIC transport is used, but certainly it's impactful for TCP flows.

comments.author: SpencerDawkins
comments.body:
Glenn, I think I can also cover this in #35 (which is still moving rapidly, so don't peek at it for a couple of days).

And I really like these observations. I know this topic matters, and I'll do my best to reflect your issue.

comments.author: SpencerDawkins
comments.body: @gitnnelg, after looking at this a bit more, I think most of the work is in what is now called the ABR section, which I haven't touched in #35. I'm going to unlink that PR, and start working on a new one. Please stay tuned.

comments.author: SpencerDawkins
comments.body:
Just to follow up here - I think the ABR section is a good start for @gitnnelg's suggested three-part section, which I'm now seeing as four sections - the fourth, describing the challenges that application-level mechanisms have to anticipate in adapting media streams.  I'm planning to use the existing subsections on Idle Time Between Segments, Head-of-Line Blocking, and Unreliable Transports in that fourth section. 

So, as @gitnnelg said - not a huge section (because where would we stop?), but some additional words that provide context for adaptive streaming.

issues.title: How badly do we need to describe ECN in ###Head-of-Line Blocking?
issues.author: SpencerDawkins
issues.body:
I'm looking at ###Head-of-Line Blocking, and most of this text looks plausible, but the last paragraph includes a short description of "classic ECN", which (AFAIK) is still not hugely employed **and turned on.** TSVWG has been actively discussing(!) proposals hat use ECT(1) as a signal that does NOT "mean the same thing as a packet loss", but until that's agreed upon and deployed - and I believe mechanisms like L4S are still targeting Experimental status, so that may take some time - there's not much difference between losing a packet and receiving a packet with one of the ECT bits set.

I can type more about the details in the draft if necessary, but do we need to talk about ECN at all?

issues.title: Describe CMCD as another measurement collection mechanism
issues.author: SpencerDawkins
issues.body:
We could reasonably start with standardized mechanisms, and could also give other examples. 

Also provide links to specifications that provide guidance on what to measure.

comments.author: acbegen
comments.body:
Replace:
In addition to measurements media players use to guide their segment-by-segment adaptive streaming requests, streaming media providers may also rely on measurements collected from media players to provide analytics that can be used for decisions such as whether the adaptive encoding bitrates in use are the best ones to provide to media players, or whether current media content caching is providing the best experience for viewers.

With:
In addition to measurements media players use to guide their segment-by-segment adaptive streaming requests, streaming media providers may also rely on measurements collected from media players to provide analytics that can be used for decisions such as whether the adaptive encoding bitrates in use are the best ones to provide to media players, or whether current media content caching is providing the best experience for viewers. To that effect, the Consumer Technology Association (CTA) who owns the Web Application Video Ecosystem (WAVE) project has published two important specifications. 

### CTA-2066: Streaming Quality of Experience Events, Properties and Metrics

CTA-2066 specifies a set of media player events, properties, quality of experience (QoE) metrics and associated terminology for representing streaming media quality of experience across systems, media players and analytics vendors. While all these events, properties, metrics and associated terminology is used across a number of proprietary analytics and measurement solutions, they were used in slightly (or vastly) different ways that led to interoperability issues. CTA-2066 attempts to address this issue by defining a common terminology as well as how each metric should be computed for consistent reporting.  

### CTA-5004: Common Media Client Data (CMCD)

Many assumes that the CDNs have a holistic view into the health and performance of the streaming clients. However, this is not the case. The CDNs produce millions of log lines per second across hundreds of thousands of clients and they have no concept of a "session" as a client would have, so CDNs are decoupled from the metrics the clients generate and report. A CDN cannot tell which request belongs to which playback session, the duration of any media object, the bitrate, or whether any of the clients have stalled and are rebuffering or are about to stall and will rebuffer. The consequence of this decoupling is that a CDN cannot prioritize delivery for when the client needs it most, prefetch content, or trigger alerts when the network itself may be underperforming. One approach to couple the CDN to the playback sessions is for the clients to communicate standardized media-relevant information to the CDNs while they are fetching data. CTA-5004 was developed exactly for this purpose.

comments.author: acbegen
comments.body:
CTA-2066: https://shop.cta.tech/products/streaming-quality-of-experience-events-properties-and-metrics
CTA-5004: https://shop.cta.tech/products/web-application-video-ecosystem-common-media-client-data-cta-5005

issues.title: Update to caching systems
issues.author: SpencerDawkins
issues.body:
From Will - 

2.3 Caching Systems

May be worth mentioning that concurrent gaming downloads nowadays drive larger traffic peaks than live or VOD streams.

Additionally, something missing from this section is the impact of chunk transfer of aggregating responses. These are being used increasingly for low latency delivery. The caching system is receiving the object in real-time while simultaneously forwarding it to the client. The object size is not known until the transmission is complete. Much of caching infrastructure failover and redundancy is predicated on knowing the size of the object you are transmitting. Distribution tiers have a hard time separating a gap in data from a failure of an upstream component. Setting appropriate time-outs becomes problematic.

comments.author: GrumpyOldTroll
comments.body:
> May be worth mentioning that concurrent gaming downloads nowadays drive larger traffic peaks than live or VOD streams.

This is a true and fine point, but I'm not sure it needs mention in a video-centric doc, except maybe how this impacts video delivery from the shared resources, but I think the congestion control sort of takes that.  I'll give it some thought, but I don't think it's really specific to caching or what we get out of raising it here, so I'm leaning toward not doing anything in this section on this point.

comments.author: GrumpyOldTroll
comments.body: I'll follow up with a separate question about the other half of this comment, I'm not quite sure what it's saying.  But it's a good point that talking about some non-intuitive failure modes might be handy here.

comments.author: SpencerDawkins
comments.body: Hi, @GrumpyOldTroll - any update here?

comments.author: GrumpyOldTroll
comments.body: Not yet.  I did send a message hoping to learn enough about the failure modes and what you can do about them to write something meaningful here, but there are some vacation-related delays and once people are back I may have to ping again.

issues.title: Idle time between segments
issues.author: SpencerDawkins
issues.body:
From Will,

3.2.1 Idle time between Segments

The section talks about consequences of mobile flow-bandwidth and TCP slow start , yet neither of these are relevant to the referenced NOSSDAV12 paper, which talks about a small cohort of adaptive players competing for bandwidth. The paper is a good one (I know one of the authors), but the RFC section text needs to do a better job of summarizing the problems highlighted by that paper.

comments.author: acbegen
comments.body:
There are two issues here: First, the on-off behavior of the HTTP streaming traffic.  NOSSDAV12 paper is a good reference describing that behavior and its consequences. This stuff is not explained much in the draft at the moment. I will look into this. Second, the TCP's slow-start restart (SSR) "feature". For that NOSSDAV12 was the wrong reference, it should have been MMSys11, which I fixed for the PR. This second issue may (or may not need further discussion). 

Can we get some feedback from CDN guys as to whether they disable SSR in production for example? @LPardue @GrumpyOldTroll ?

comments.author: GrumpyOldTroll
comments.body:
In practice we do a number of things, including some different handling of SSR.  It can be a little complicated because it can depend on what has happened in the flow, so "disabled" might not be exactly the way to think about it, and I think different settings in the config for your assets can perhaps result in different behavior.  I expect also different CDNs have different answers.
This text was intended to raise this as an effect to be aware of if you're operating a server, and a point to check when you're troubleshooting why something is not behaving as expected.  I guess there might be something useful to say about CDNs and other providers that already have techniques in place to mitigate this, is that what you're asking about here?

comments.author: LPardue
comments.body: Not commenting on a specific CDN but, as a general observation, many people tuning HTTP performance will start with something like https://hpbn.co/building-blocks-of-tcp/, which includes some advice for best current practice including disabling SSR

comments.author: SpencerDawkins
comments.body: Fixed in #59.

issues.title: Refactoring Adaptive Segmented Delivery subsections to focus on reasons why signals are lower or higher than they should be
issues.author: SpencerDawkins
issues.body:
The editors are 2:1 in favor of dropping ECN. Spencer is graciously in the rough. 

We should be talking more broadly about what happens when you lose *any* packets, 

If ECN belongs in the draft, it belongs somewhere else. 

"Coming improvements in transport behaviors" more broadly - we're talking about BBR and about end-to-end transport encryption now. Maybe we should talk about things like edge computing, etc ... but @GrumpyOldTroll will talk to the working group about this before we start a major refactor.

comments.author: GrumpyOldTroll
comments.body:
The point of these sections (4.3.1 Idle Time Between Segments and 4.3.2 Head of Line Blocking) was to explain how and why your bandwidth measurements can go wrong when you're trying to do ABR things with your bandwidth measurements.

By name this seems like perhaps a better fit in the 4.4 Measurement Collection section, there might be a reason to merge some of the discussion there or reorganize the 2 sections together.

comments.author: GrumpyOldTroll
comments.body: We maybe should also add a section along these lines on the wide variability in bitrates as things move, both for wi-fi and LTE and 5g. (or paths in general, with those as examples?)

comments.author: GrumpyOldTroll
comments.body: Note also: "Refactor" here means provide a coherent story for why your ABR measurements can go wrong and what you can do about it.

@ldaigle and @squarooticus - the plan is that this draft will have a "living section pointing to further reading", that would be maintained by the working group. This issue is complete (in our opinion), but I've tagged it with the "documentation" label, and I'll leave this issue open until you have a chance to comment on the proposed text, or otherwise grab it for chair use as appropriate. 

> _**Note: (currently section 7) "Further Reading and References", is intended to be maintained as a useful resource for streaming operators in understanding relevant technologies, especially as they evolve over time. For this reason, the plan is that the contents of this section will be copied to a non-archival web resource (likely as an IETF-owned wiki) at AUTH48 time, so that this section in the published RFC will match the non-archival web resource on the day of RFC publication.**_ 

> _**Note to the RFC Editor: please coordinate with the document authors during AUTH48 to ensure that this section in the RFC matches the non-archival web resource on the day of RFC publication.**_ 

If anyone kidnaps you demanding to know what the plan is for maintenance, I'd suggest "the MOPS working group will maintain the non-archival resource as updates are needed", but I'd wait for someone to ask the question before saying that out loud. 

Do The Right Thing, of Course.

issues.title: Considerations on cloud-based encoding, packaging and origin workflows
issues.author: acbegen
issues.body:
The encoder sync workshop revealed lots of problems and unfortunately a little solution to synchronized encoding and packaging that are essential in large scale events. 

Should we touch on these topics in this draft as they seem to be quite related to "operational considerations", mostly in the sense that we raise awareness instead of listing/proposing solutions.

Thoughts?

comments.author: SpencerDawkins
comments.body:
@squarooticus and @ldaigle - this is the pointer to the workshop that @acbegen mentioned in this issue. It was quite good. 

https://sites.google.com/view/encodersyncworkshop

On our editors call yesterday, we talked about whether this is material that should be in 
draft-ietf-mops-streaming-opcons. We were leaning toward "yes", but also recognizing that this is new material that the working group hasn't discussed (so not likely we can get to WGLC by Monday, when the I-D cutoff happens). 

I asked if this was a candidate for a second I-D, focused on encoder synchronization, but we couldn't think of a good reason NOT to include this topic in draft-ietf-mops-streaming-opcons, if we were going to document it in MOPS. 

You two could reasonably make a decision about that, or bring this up on the mailing list to get feedback from the working group, or (probably several other alternatives). Can we defer to the chairs for guidance about this?

Best,

Spencer

comments.author: squarooticus
comments.body:
Sorry for the late reply: somehow I missed the mention in my inbox.

I don't see any reason why this should be out of scope. If you have time, I'd say add some proposed text prior to the cutoff later today and then post a summary of this to the list. We can raise the question at the 111 session and do a consensus call if there are any objections.

comments.author: gitnnelg
comments.body:
I agree with Kyle that it’s not out of scope, but I do suggest that we attempt to be thoughtful of keeping the focus on IETF related aspects – networks, routing, network & transport protocols, addressing – so as to avoid wading too deep into the higher level aspects of Encoding and Packaging.

I guess what I’m trying to say, is conscious effort is needed to avoid getting into weeds that don’t directly connect with the IETF’s technical interests.  If we did go into the weeds, we’d be covering material that won’t connect with the IETF reader and might even leave them behind.

-glenn

I don't see any reason why this should be out of scope. If you have time, I'd say add some proposed text prior to the cutoff later today and then post a summary of this to the list. We can raise the question at the 111 session and do a consensus call if there are any objections.

comments.author: squarooticus
comments.body: That's a very good point, Glenn. If this has implications for transport, network QoS, scalability, etc., then it may be relevant.

comments.author: SpencerDawkins
comments.body:
Re: IETF-related aspects, we should remember that we do have IETF working groups that touch on this topic, even if they are in ART, so I wouldn't worry about that. 

So, after thinking about comments from others, my other question is how much of the material we are talking about is well-understood and roughly agreed upon. Most of what we've got in the current version of the draft is either well-understood or at least has consensus behind it (example - the material about QUIC isn't as mature as the material about TCP, but I think it's mature enough). I might think that the point of having the Synchronization workshop was that we don't have as much of a handle on that yet. Unless we do understand that well enough to provide input about potential new work in the IETF, maybe it IS worth holding off on this, and doing a separate document when we can be confident. 

But this is definitely worth putting in front of the working group at IETF 111, no matter what the working group decides.

issues.title: Segment size and keyframe intervals
issues.author: GrumpyOldTroll
issues.body:
Describe in general terms segments and frame types, tradeoffs associated with segment size and keyframe interval selection. (related to idle-time and caching)

Thanks @englishm-ietf for the suggestion as part of https://github.com/ietf-wg-mops/draft-ietf-mops-streaming-opcons/pull/85

comments.author: SpencerDawkins
comments.body:
This is about low-latency and where you can start rendering in a media stream. 

Mention and explain briefly? This isn't quite about the NETWORK, but it's about caching, which is probably in the network. 

Keyframes can also be used for thumbnails when you hover over something. 

More keyframes gives you more flexibility in where you can start rendering, but is also larger and comes with a bandwidth and path occupancy cost.

comments.author: SpencerDawkins
comments.body: Insert this material in "For further reading" (#14}?

comments.author: englishm-ietf
comments.body: My thought here was that stream characteristics like GOP sizing place a constraint on switching opportunities for renditions (ABR) and ad insertion, which can have an impact on bandwidth utilization, etc. I thought some explanatory text might help pull those sections together a bit more, but I'm fine with it just being covered in the further reading, too.

comments.author: acbegen
comments.body:
> My thought here was that stream characteristics like GOP sizing place a constraint on switching opportunities for renditions (ABR) and ad insertion, which can have an impact on bandwidth utilization, etc. I thought some explanatory text might help pull those sections together a bit more, but I'm fine with it just being covered in the further reading, too.

It is not very easy to correctly discuss the trade-offs between the key frame internal, segment size, encoding quality, impact on the storage, request rate and all that. There are detailed studies that do an excellent job on explaining these trade-offs, so referring the readers to these studies is better IMO.

https://github.com/ietf-wg-mops/draft-ietf-mops-streaming-opcons/pull/18/files#diff-5be99afc1cea1f534a1a3c1ee314a58b61234fb293a45bdcea323b8fcfb24301R233-R236

comments.author: SpencerDawkins
comments.body: We THINK this is different from general DNS performance impacts, when you do client side ad insertion for URLs that the media provider is handing you based on the specific customer who is looking at the media. The actual problem is probably media player-specific, but but we can probably say something useful in a sentence or two.

comments.author: GrumpyOldTroll
comments.body: BTW: comments are welcomed on whether or not we should acknowledge the existence of DNS-based ad-blockers and their relevance to this issue in this document.

comments.author: SpencerDawkins
comments.body:
So, now that I've slept on this (sort of), I was leaning toward adding at least a sentence or two about DNS-based ad-blockers, because that was a topic I THOUGHT I understood, but apparently not in much depth. ISTM that the question I SHOULD have asked, is "that's a fascinating question. Is there anything that a media provider can do differently, if we describe the issue?"

ISTM that if what we say would be actionable for the designated audience, it makes sense to say it in the draft.

comments.author: GrumpyOldTroll
comments.body:
If a player implementer is aware of the potential for trouble from a change in hostname for a stream, they could run that request a little early as a mitigation to give time for the DNS to settle out, or to do any kind of pre-request to an upcoming non-recently-used hostname or something.  Also the operator could chose to run server-side ads instead.  (That might not be an exhaustive list, but it's at least a couple examples.)
Maybe also worth mentioning it can be more of an issue if you're running a tight latency budget.  But yeah, I think it's at least somewhat actionable for operators if the issue is on their radar.

issues.title: Ultra Low-Latency Capabilities
issues.author: kenyonja
issues.body:
Regarding the statements in clause 3.1 about a lack of success in Ultra Low-Latency streaming, and that replicating streams is "nearly impossible to achieve", there are implementers that are able to stream content to audiences numbering in the hundreds of thousands with a latency of less than half a second.  

Suggest revisiting this area of the text to note that, while delivering ultra low-latency content to large audiences can be challenging, it is indeed possible.

comments.author: gitnnelg
comments.body:
On 8/24/21, 10:25 AM, "kenyonja" ***@***.******@***.***>> wrote:


Regarding the statements in clause 3.1 about a lack of success in Ultra Low-Latency streaming, and that replicating streams is "nearly impossible to achieve", there are implementers that are able to stream content to audiences numbering in the hundreds of thousands with a latency of less than half a second.

Suggest revisiting this area of the text to note that, while delivering ultra low-latency content to large audiences can be challenging, it is indeed possible.



Do you have examples of services that are doing sub 0.5s at the scale of hundreds od thousands?    What I’ve understood from services going ULL streaming is that they focus on a sub-set core of participants which get the ULL delivery, with the remainder of participants getting a slightly high latency delivery.    So they are effectively are providing a range of latencies to different groups all watching the same event.

If there are services that have figured out how to do everyone at ULL that would be good citations to consider including.

-glenn

comments.author: acbegen
comments.body:
OK here is our proposal for the 2nd parag. in Section 3.1:

Some media content providers aim to achieve this level of latency for live media events involving sports. This introduces new challenges relative to less-restricted levels of latency requirements because this latency is the same scale as commonly observed end-to-end network latency variation (for example, due to effects such as bufferbloat, Wi-Fi error correction, or packet reordering). These effects can make it difficult to achieve this level of latency for the general case, and may require tradeoffs in relatively frequent user-visible media artifacts. However, for controlled environments or targeted networks that provide mitigations against such effects, this level of latency is potentially achievable with the right provisioning.

Worth noting is that many applications for ultra low-latency delivery do not need to scale to more than a few users at a time, which simplifies many delivery considerations relative to other use cases.

pulls.title: Update draft-jholland-mops-taxonomy.md
pulls.author: SpencerDawkins
pulls.body:
---
title: Operational Considerations for Streaming Media
abbrev: Media Streaming Ops
docname: draft-jholland-mops-taxonomy-01
date: 2020-01-17
category: info

ipr: trust200902
area: Ops
workgroup: Mops
keyword: Internet-Draft

stand_alone: yes
pi: [toc, sortrefs, symrefs]

author:
 -
    ins: J. Holland
    name: Jake Holland
    org: Akamai Technologies, Inc.
    street: 150 Broadway
    city: Cambridge, MA 02144
    country: United States of America
    email: jakeholland.net@gmail.com

informative:
  CVNI:
    target: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/solutions/collateral/service-provider/visual-networking-index-vni/white-paper-c11-741490.html
    title: "Cisco Visual Networking Index: Forecast and Trends, 2017–2022 White Paper"
    author:
      - 
        org: "Cisco Systems, Inc."
    date: 2019-02-27
  DASH:
    title: "Information technology -- Dynamic adaptive streaming over HTTP (DASH) -- Part 1: Media presentation description and segment formats"
    seriesinfo:
      "ISO/IEC": 23009-1:2014
    date: 2014-05
  MSOD:
    title: "Media Services On Demand: Encoder Best Practices"
    author:
      - 
        org: "Akamai Technologies, Inc."
    target: https://learn.akamai.com/en-us/webhelp/media-services-on-demand/media-services-on-demand-encoder-best-practices/GUID-7448548A-A96F-4D03-9E2D-4A4BBB6EC071.html
    date: 2019
  RFC2309:
  RFC3168:
  RFC5594:
  RFC5762:
  RFC6190:
  RFC8033:
  RFC8216:
  I-D.han-iccrg-arvr-transport-problem:

--- abstract

This document provides an overview of operational networking issues
that pertain to quality of experience in delivery of video and other
high-bitrate media over the internet.

--- middle

#Introduction {#intro}

As the internet has grown, an increasingly large share of the traffic
delivered to end users has become video.  Estimates
put the total share of internet video traffic at 75% in 2019, expected
to grow to 82% by 2022.  What's more, this estimate projects the
gross volume of video traffic will more than double during this time,
based on a compound annual growth rate continuing at 34% (from Appendix
D of {{CVNI}}).

In many contexts, video traffic can be handled transparently as
generic application-level traffic.  However, as the volume of
video traffic continues to grow, it's becoming increasingly
important to consider the effects of network design decisions
on application-level performance, with considerations for
the impact on video delivery.

This document aims to provide a taxonomy of networking issues as
they relate to quality of experience in internet video delivery.
The focus is on capturing characteristics of video delivery that
have surprised network designers or transport experts without
specific video expertise, since these highlight key differences
between common assumptions in existing networking documents and
observations of video delivery issues in practice.

Making specific recommendations for mitigating these issues
is out of scope, though some existing mitigations are mentioned
in passing.  The intent is to provide a point of reference for
future solution proposals to use in describing how new
technologies address or avoid these existing observed problems.

#Bandwidth Provisioning

##Scaling Requirements for Media Delivery {#scaling}

###Video Bitrates

Video bit-rate selection depends on many variables.  Different
providers give different guidelines, but an equation that
approximately matches the bandwidth requirement estimates
from several video providers is given in {{MSOD}}:

~~~
Kbps = (HEIGHT * WIDTH * FRAME_RATE) / (7 * 1024)
~~~

Height and width are in pixels, and frame rate in frames per second.
The actual bit-rate required for a specific video will also depend on the
codec used and some other characteristics of the video itself, such
as the frequency of high-detail motion, which may influence the
compressability of the content, but this equation provides a rough
estimate.

Here are a few common resolutions used for video content, with their
minimum per-user bandwidth requirements according to this formula:

| Name | Width x Height | Approximate Bit-rate for 60fps
| -----+----------------+-------------------------------
| DVD |  720 x 480 | 3 Mbps
| 720p | 1280 x 720 | 8 Mbps
| 1080p | 1920 x 1080 | 18 Mbps
| 2160p (4k) | 3840 x 2160 | 70 Mbps

###Virtual Reality Bitrates

TBD: Reference and/or adapt content from expired
work-in-progress {{I-D.han-iccrg-arvr-transport-problem}}.

The punchline is that it starts at a bare minimum of 22 Mbps
mean with a 130 Mbps peak rate, up to 3.3 Gbps mean with 38 Gbps
peak for high-end technology.

##Path Requirements

The bit-rate requirements in {{scaling}} are per end-user actively
consuming a media feed, so in the worst case, the bit-rate demands
can be multiplied by the number of simultaneous users to find the
bandwidth requirements for a router on the delivery path with that
number of users downstream.  For example, at a node with 10,000
downstream users simultaneously consuming video streams,
approximately up to 180 Gbps would be necessary in order for all
of them to get 1080p resolution at 60 fps.

However, when there is some overlap in the feeds being consumed by
end users, it is sometimes possible to reduce the bandwidth
provisioning requirements for the network by performing some kind
of replication within the network.  This can be achieved via object
caching with delivery of replicated objects over individual
connections, and/or by packet-level replication using multicast.

To the extent that replication of popular content can be performed,
bandwidth requirements at peering or ingest points can be reduced to
as low as a per-feed requirement instead of a per-user requirement.

##Caching Systems

TBD: pros, cons, tradeoffs of caching designs at different locations within
the network?

Peak vs. average provisioning, and effects on peering point congestion
under peak load?

Provisioning issues for caching systems?

##Predictable Usage Profiles

TBD: insert charts showing historical relative data usage patterns with
error bars by time of day in consumer networks?

Cross-ref vs. video quality by time of day in practice for some case
study?  Not sure if there's a good way to capture a generalized insight
here, but it seems worth making the point that demand projections can
be used to help with e.g. power consumption with routing architectures
that provide for modular scalability.

##Unpredictable Usage Profiles

Although TCP/IP has been used with a number of widely used applications that have symmetric bandwidth requirements (similar bandwidth requirements in each direction between endpoints), many widely-used Internet applications operate in client-server roles, with asymmetric bandwidth requirements. A common example might be an HTTP GET operation, where a client sends a relatively small HTTP GET request for a resource to an HTTP server, and often receives a significantly larger response carrying the requested resource. When HTTP is commonly used to stream movie-length video, the ratio between response size and request size can become quite large. 

For this reason, operators may pay more attention to downstream bandwidth utilization when planning and managing capacity. In addition, operators have been able to deploy access networks for end users using underlying technologies that are inherently asymetric, favoring downstream bandwidth (e.g. ADSL, cellular technologies, most IEEE 802.11 variants), assuming that users will need less upstream bandwidth than downstream bandwidth. This strategy usually works, except when it does not, because application bandwidth usage patterns have changed. 

One example of this type of change was when peer-to-peer file sharing applications gained popularity in the early 2000s. To take one well-documented case ({{RFC5594}}), the Bittorrent application created "swarms" of hosts, uploading and downloading files to each other, rather than communicating with a server. Bittorrent favored peers who uploaded as much as they downloaded, so that new Bittorrent users had an incentive to significantly increased their upstream bandwidth utilization. 

One example of this type of change was when peer-to-peer file sharing applications gained popularity in the early 2000s. To take one well-documented case ({{RFC5594}}), the Bittorrent application created "swarms" of hosts, uploading and downloading files to each other, rather than communicating with a server. Bittorrent favored peers who uploaded as much as they downloaded, so that new Bittorrent users had an incentive to significantly increased their upstream bandwidth utilization. 

The combination of the large volume of "torrents" and the peer-to-peer characteristic of swarm transfers meant that end user hosts were suddenly uploading higher volumes of traffic to more destinations than was the case before Bittorrent. This caused at least one large ISP to attempt to "throttle" these transfers, to mitigate the load that these hosts placed on their network. These efforts were met by increased use of encryption in Bittorrent, similar to an arms race, and set off discussions about "Net Neutrality" and calls for regulatory action.

Especially as end users increase use of video-based social networking applications, it will be helpful for access network providers to watch for applications that encourage end users to upload significant amounts of content. 

#Adaptive Bit Rate

##Overview

Adaptive Bit-Rate (ABR) is a sort of application-level congestion
response strategy in which the receiving media player attempts to
detect the available bandwidth of the network path by experiment
or by observing the successful application-layer download speed,
then chooses a video bitrate that fits within that bandwidth,
typically adjusting as changes in available bandwidth occur in
the network.

The choice of bit-rate occurs within the context of optimizing for
some metric monitored by the video player, such as highest achievable
video quality, or lowest rate of expected rebuffering events.

##Segmented Delivery

ABR strategies are commonly implemented by video players using HLS
{{RFC8216}} or DASH {{DASH}} to perform a reliable segment delivery
of video data over HTTP.  Different player implementations and
receiving devices use different strategies, often proprietary
algorithms, to perform the bit-rate selection and available
bandwidth estimation.

This kind of bandwidth-detection system can experience trouble in
several ways that can be affected by networking design choices.

###Idle Time Between Segments

When the bit-rate selection is successfully chosen below the
available capacity of the network path, the response to a
segment request will complete in less absolute time than the
video bit-rate speed.

The resulting idle time within the connection carrying the
segments has a few surprising consequences:

 * Mobile flow-bandwidth spectrum and timing mapping.

 * TCP Slow-start when restarting after idle requires multiple
   RTTs to re-establish a throughput at the network's available
   capacity.  On high-RTT paths or with small enough segments,
   this can produce a falsely low application-visible measurement
   of the available network capacity.

###Head of Line Blocking

In the event of a lost packet on a TCP connection with SACK
support (a common case for segmented delivery in practice), loss
of a packet can provide a confusing bandwidth signal to the
receiving application.  Because of the sliding window in TCP,
many packets may be accepted by the receiver without being available
to the application until the missing packet arrives.  Upon arrival
of the one missing packet after retransmit, the receiver will
suddenly get access to a lot of data at the same time.

To a receiver measuring bytes received per unit time at the
application layer, and interpreting it as an estimate of the
available network bandwidth, this appears as a high jitter in
the goodput measurement.

Active Queue Management (AQM) systems such as PIE {{RFC8033}} or
variants of RED {{RFC2309}}} that induce early random loss under
congestion can mitigate this by using ECN {{RFC3168}} where
available.  ECN provides a congestion signal and induce a similar
backoff in flows that use Explicit Congestion Notification-capable
transport, but by avoiding loss avoids inducing head-of-line blocking
effects in TCP connections.

##Unreliable Transport

In contrast to segmented delivery, several applications use UDP or
unreliable SCTP to deliver RTP or raw TS-formatted video.

Under congestion and loss, this approach generally experiences more
video artifacts with fewer delay or head of line blocking effects.
Often one of the key goals is to reduce latency, to better support
applications like video conferencing, or for other live-action
video with interactive components, such as some sporting events.

Congestion avoidance strategies for this kind of deployment vary
widely in practice, ranging from some streams that are entirely
unresponsive to using feedback signaling to change encoder settings
(as in {{RFC5762}}), or to use fewer enhancement layers (as in
{{RFC6190}}), to proprietary methods for detecting quality of
experience issues and cutting off video.

# Doc History and Side Notes

Note to RFC Editor: Please remove this section before publication

TBD: suggestion from mic at IETF 106 (Mark Nottingham): dive into
the different constraints coming from different parts of the network
or distribution channels. (regarding questions about how to describe
the disconnect between demand vs. capacity, while keeping good archival
value.)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4_k340xT2jM&t=13m

TBD: suggestion from mic at IETF 106 (Dave Oran + Glenn Deen responding):
pre-placement for many use cases is useful--distinguish between live vs.
cacheable.  "People assume high-demand == live, but not always true" with
popular netflix example.

(Glenn): something about latency requirements for cached vs. streaming on
live vs.  pre-recorded content, and breaking requirements into 2 separate
charts.  also: "Standardized ladder" for adaptive bit rate rates suggested,
declined as out of scope.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4_k340xT2jM&t=14m15s

TBD: suggestion at the mic from IETF 106 (Aaron Falk): include
industry standard metrics from citations, some standard scoping metrics
may be already defined.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4_k340xT2jM&t=19m15s

#IANA Considerations

This document requires no actions from IANA.

#Security Considerations

This document introduces no new security issues.

--- back

pulls.title: Proposed fix for issue #3 (latency section)
pulls.author: GrumpyOldTroll
pulls.body: At long last here is a strawman proposal for a latency-relevant section, for discussion in the upcoming interim.

comments.author: acbegen
comments.body:
>   * ultra low latency    (less than 1 second)
>   * low latency live     (less than 10 seconds)
>   * non-low-latency live (10 seconds to a few minutes)
>   * on-demand            (hours or more)

The meaning of low latency has changed significantly in the last few years. With DASH-LL and LL-HLS, people are now looking at 2-5 seconds of latency (so that is low latency). For latencies lower than 1s, at the ms level, cloud gaming for example, that is what ultra low latency nowadays means. FWIW, companies offering streaming solutions using WebRTC claim their solutions are ULL and others are only LL.

comments.author: SpencerDawkins

The mention is good, but the wording  doesn't reflect how the situation is still developing.      Is it worth mentioning the different use cases for Ultra LL?      Game watching like Twitch is one use case, while live sports is a different one.

I recall in a talk at MileHighVideo in August 2019 on LL streaming that to get there LL services are delivering simultaneously 2 levels of latency to users.   One class gets the fastest LL.  Users get added into this fast LL class until that serving resource gets to its load level.  A second class of higher latency (slower) users are then created using a different delivery that isn't as fast, but scales to more users.      

This aspect may be worth documenting as handling migration/handoff between these two classes could be a use case ultimately.

> If we do want to mention workflow stages here, the recent SVA document, "Best Practices for End-to-End Workflow Monitoring" may be a useful reference.

...was also a link to that same page. 😄

IMHO the ingest use case is important. When latency is important, this is the segment where RTMP seems to be the most used nowadays. Beyond RTMP, It s difficult to draw the line though. If we wanted to be more inclusive, SRT is being used (by people with a haivision encoder), RIST is being used, RTSP is being used (especially for surveillance camera), and even raw RTP (AWS kinetic), or webrtc (millicast.com).

Very often the protocol choice seems to be dictated by the existing hardware.

Most of the time, with the exception of RTSP/RTP/webrtc, it includes a transcoding step in the media path which adds latency. The added latency is at least one frame (33ms), but depends on the depth of the frame buffer, and is usually inconsequential unless you are aiming for real-time (gaming, ...) where your total glass to glass latency budget is usually 150~200 ms. A recent peer-reviewed study on comparison of encoders for real-time content touches on that point [preprint](https://arxiv.org/abs/2009.14165)

I could not find an authoritative source on corresponding volumes, even though bitomovin 2020 report put them in that order: HLS > RTMP > webrtc. I believe this makes sense only if you take "slow live" (more than 10s) into account, and there HLS prevails, otherwise the consensus is that RTMP prevails.

To make supporting WebRTC ingest easier, especially for hardware encoders, there is an ongoing IETF effort and a proposed Draft. It's going through Dispatch this time around, so it s too early to put it in this document, but I wanted to bring it to the attention of the group, and it could be of interest for discussion in march, dispatch willing.
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-murillo-whip/

Great comments in this thread, thanks!

This discussion makes me think maybe the right thing is to open yet another issue about writing a section that outlines workflow stages in a glass to glass pipeline (for which I agree the SVA doc looks like a very good reference).

I think of particular interest for this doc would be a focus on where the transport between stages does or does not commonly happen over IP networks, along with pointers to commonly used technologies and a brief summary of the networking considerations (like the pros and cons, provisioning and reliability requirements, along with common failure modes and their causes).

I think having such a section about workflow stages would help a lot with establishing better context for this latency section.  So I'll leave some time to raise objections (and maybe even ask the wg opinion tomorrow), but otherwise plan to open that issue shortly, unless someone has a better suggestion.

comments.body: I agree with @squarooticus here. At a minimum, ISTM there's a hole between "a few minutes" and "hours or more", that I don't know what to do with.

> Is it worth mentioning the continued use of [Adobe RTMP](https://rtmp.veriskope.com/docs/spec/) here, particularly common still as an ingest protocol?

I would vote for not including this. RTMP is nearing its death (Adobe is no longer supporting it and content providers are migrating from it), leaving the space to newer approaches like SRT, RIST, Zixi.

For Twitch, our primary driving factor has been to reduce latency for the sake of chat. A user can leave a comment on a live stream and the broadcaster will read it in real-time. However, latency causes the broadcaster's verbal response to be delayed.

It might be worth generalizing this as any form of social chatter. This includes being able to influence the broadcast itself.

Two levels of protection: media-level and transport-level. Media-level encryption is for business purposes, to avoid piracy, playback controls, etc. Transport-level encryption is for avoiding others from messing with your stuff (like manifest or media segments). comments.body: @GrumpyOldTroll and @acbegen, I think this PR is ready to merge. Do either of you agree?

```suggestion
It's also worth pointing out that because UDP has no transport-layer feedback mechanisms, UDP-based applications that expect to send and receive substantial amounts of information must provide their own feedback mechanisms. RTP relies on RTCP Sender and Receiver Reports {{RFC3550}} as its own feedback mechanism, and even includes Circuit Breakers for Unicast RTP Sessions {{RFC8083}} for situations when normal RTP congestion control has not been able to react sufficiently to RTP flows sending at rates that result in sustained packet loss.
```

maybe a typo?
nit: there's a bit of redundancy here and elsewhere in the PR with e.g. "UDP Protocol"

```suggestion
For most of the history of the Internet, we have trusted the TCP protocol to limit the impact of applications that sent a significant number of packets, in either or both directions, on other users. Although early versions of TCP were not particularly good at limiting this impact {{RFC0793}}, the addition of Slow Start and Congestion Avoidance, as described in {{RFC2001}}, were critical in allowing TCP-based applications to "use as much bandwidth as possible, but to avoid using more bandwidth than was possible". Although dozens of RFCs have been written refining TCP decisions about what to send, how much to send, and when to send it, since 1988 {{Jacobson-Karels}} the signals available for TCP senders remained unchanged - end-to-end acknowledgments for packets that were successfully sent and received, and packet timeouts for packets that were not. 
```

the sentences here are a bit long. Would recommend to break them up a little.

I also personally wouldn't call HTTP a new protocol :D
this is a very long sentence

I don't think you need two references to {{I-D.ietf-quic-transport}} but I'll let you pick which one to use.

It would probably help to clearly state that QUIC is transport protocol that offer an alternative to UDP and TCP but *is* based on UDP. I would also move the mention of encryption in 3rd paragraph up to here.

As someone overly familiar with HTTP/3 this paragraph reads a bit strangely. 

I might rephrase it to something like below (and defer to your editor capabilites to make it even better)

The QUIC transport protocol can carry different application-later protocols. HTTP/3 {{I-D.ietf-quic-http}} describes how QUIC transport features are used for HTTP. The convention is for HTTP/3 to run over UDP port 443 {{Port443}} but this is not a strict requirement. Since earlier versions of HTTP(S) rely on TCP, UDP ports may blocked for any values that are not commonly used, such as UDP 53 for DNS. Where UDP ports are not blocked and HTTP/3 can flow, streaming operators (and network operators) might see QUIC traffic patterns that are similar to HTTP(S) over TCP. Where ports are open, they may be servery rate-limited because operators may not be used to seeing legitimate high-bandwidth traffic such as streaming, over the ports that HTTP/3 tends to use.

I would invert the sentences about QUIC a a little and say:

QUIC {{I-D.ietf-quic-transport}} provides a set of congestion control hooks that can be use for algorithm agility. {{I-D.ietf-quic-recovery}} defines a basic algorithm that behaves roughly similar TCP NewReno {{RFC6582}}. However, QUIC senders can and do unilaterally chose to use different algorithms such as loss-based CUBIC {{RFC8312}}, delay-based COPA or BBR, or even something completely different
how about adding some links to the QUIC operability draft?

I think there is a sublte point that is hard to make here. I'd be surprised if operators rolled a QUIC version just to deploy a different CC - that is the beauty of sender unilateral descisions. However, what we might see is that protocol evolution can support new or better approaches to CC. For example, Christians's proposed one-way delay measurement extension. Tangentially, some experimenters might want to add transport feautres that need alternative CC, and it can be easier to run an experimental version of QUIC to prove a hypothesis rather than try to hook into extension mechanisms.

I really don't know best to present such nuance here. All I can suggest is to focus on concerns your target audience has, rather than nitty gritty QUIC detail.s

Yeah, I honestly expect this needs broader discussion (@LPardue is seeing this text at the same time as my co-authors, so it's had a total of four eyes on it, so far). I worked on this a bit for readability, but I'm pretty sure we'll be back after we submit -04 ...

```suggestion
While QUIC is designed as a general-purpose transport protocol, and can carry different application-layer protocols, the current standardized mapping is for HTTP/3 {{I-D.ietf-quic-http}}, which describes how QUIC transport features are used for HTTP. The convention is for HTTP/3 to run over UDP port 443 {{Port443}} but this is not a strict requirement.
```

```suggestion
When HTTP/3 is encapsulated in QUIC, which is then encapsulated in UDP, streaming operators (and network operators) might see UDP traffic patterns that are similar to HTTP(S) over TCP. Since earlier versions of HTTP(S) rely on TCP, UDP ports may be blocked for any port numbers that are not commonly used, such as UDP 53 for DNS. Even when UDP ports are not blocked and HTTP/3 can flow, streaming operators (and network operators) may severely rate-limit this traffic because they do not expect to see legitimate high-bandwidth traffic such as streaming, over the UDP ports that HTTP/3 tends to use.
```

Hi, @GrumpyOldTroll - more broadly, up through at least -02, and maybe -03, it felt like we were describing where streaming media WAS, and now we're adding material that's describing where streaming media is GOING. Does that make sense? 

We didn't punt the issues out of GitHub, and I sure don't disagree with including material on heavily encrypted and agile QUIC, which is now approved for publication and being broadly deployed, so saying "come back in a couple of years, and we'll explain what you should have done" is wrong. But it is ... different. 

Re: location - we'll do the right thing. I'm the kind of transport guy that thinks congestion control, contention, and fairness are fundamental, but I'd rather put them in the right place than keep them up front for religious reasons!
And I did fix the paren. You know, the least of our problems :D

comments.body: I merged this PR based on comments above with @gitnnelg so that we'll have it in the next draft we submit.

Many delivery systems do a test delivery to clients to do an initial test of bandwidth for the playout to follow.    So perhaps a better wording would be:

Many server-player systems will do an initial probe or a very simple throughput speed test at the start of a video play.   This is done to get a rough sense of the highest video bit rate in the ABR ladder that the network between the server and player will likely be expected under current network conditions.   After the initial testing, clients tend to rely upon passive network observations and will make use of player side statistics such buffer fill rates to monitor and respond to changing network conditions.

The media server may also choose to alter which bitrates are made available to players by adding or removing bitrate options from the ladder delivered to the player in subsequent manifests built and sent to the player.   

In this way both the player, through its selection of bitrate to request from the manifest, and the server, through its construction of the bitrates offered in the manifest, are able to affect the network utilization.
I used this text with very few changes. Thanks for sending text!
I used this text with like, 2 editorial changes. Thanks for your help on this!

comments.author: GrumpyOldTroll
comments.body:
I had a few comments in the prior pr, but I'm not sure I quite got across what I meant.

I drafted an alternative proposal as a quick straw man example of what I meant, maybe we could do some merger that includes some content along these lines?

I was also thinking to put it in the ABR section instead of the bandwidth section, probably.  Not sure if this goes too far?

~~~
## Advertising

For many use cases advertising plays a critical role in the business decision to stream an event, so advertising often is included as part of streaming media over the internet.
Some commonly used forms of advertising can introduce potential user experience issues for a media stream.
This section provides a very brief overview of a complex and evolving space, but a complete coverage of the potential issues is out of scope for this document.

ABR media can dynamically insert ads with either Client Side Ad Insertion (CSAI) or Server Side Ad Insertion (SSAI).
In CSAI, the ABR manifest will generally include links to an external ad server for some segments of the media stream, while in SSAI the server will remain the same during advertisements, but will include media segments that contain the advertising.
In SSAI, the media segments may or may not be sourced from an external ad server like with CSAI.

In some cases, especially with SSAI, advertising space in a stream is reserved for a specific advertiser and can be integrated with the video so that the segments share the same encoding properties such as bitrate, dynamic range, and resolution.
However, in many cases ad servers integrate with a Supply Side Platform (SSP) that offers advertising space in real-time auctions via an Ad Exchange, with bids for the advertising space coming from Demand Side Platforms (DSPs) that collect money from advertisers for delivering the advertisements.
Most such Ad Exchanges use application-level protocol specifications published by the Interactive Advertising Bureau {{IAB-ADS}}, an industry trade organization.

This ecosystem balances several competing objectives, and integrating with it naively can produce surprising user experience results.
For example, ad server provisioning and/or the bitrate of the ad segments might be different from that of the main video, either of which can sometimes result in video stalls.
For another example, since the inserted ads are often produced independently they might have a different base volume level than the main video, which can make for a jarring user experience.

Additionally, this market historically has had incidents of ad fraud (misreporting of ad delivery to end users for financial gain).
As a mitigation for concerns driven by those incidents, some SSPs have required the use of players with features like reporting of ad delivery, or providing information that can be used for user tracking.
Some of these and other measures have raised privacy concerns for end users.

In general this is a rapidly developing space with many considerations, and media streaming operators engaged in advertising may need to research these and other concerns to find solutions that meet their user experience, user privacy, and financial goals.
For further reading on mitigations, {{BAP}} has published some standards and best practices based on user experience research.

IAB-ADS: iab.com
BAP: https://www.betterads.org
~~~

Since we're going to be doing a final editorial pass anyway, I'm merging this PR and closing the issue now. I don't see us making significant changes to the current proposed text - as Jake says, it looks quite good.

Not much or very specifically, but I'll give my own take:
There was a point when it was probably open to add another author that would take on a range of new issues and the various tasks involved in getting this doc to a publishable state, but that's probably a bit late by now, assuming nothing goes too terribly wrong.  The PR has a significant contribution for which I'm grateful, but I don't think it's quite the same as going into the author's list as it stands.

But with that said, it's definitely true that a few people have contributed at a significantly higher level than some of the others, and this is a good candidate for one of them--it tends to lean toward "above and beyond" to post several paragraphs of proposed draft text, as opposed to hand-waving at a general point for the authors to address from the mic line.  Although that latter is also a welcome kind of feedback, in some cases it's harder to turn into a value-add to the doc than proposed text is.

I guess the relevant advice is Sections 4.10 and 4.11 from RFC 7322, and they seem to leave a wide latitude on how exactly to do it:
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7322#section-4.10

I haven't seen many RFCs that differentiate by level of effort in the Acknowledgements section or add a Contributor's section, but if a highlighted call-out of some sort would be meaningful there, we could try discussing the best way to put such a thing?  Or maybe you and he would rather have an offer of a beer with a personal thank-you next time we're in the same area, and go in the regular list of acknowledgements instead of the authors?  I'm basically aiming to land on nobody feeling slighted here while taking all the contributions that improve the doc.

But I think that summary is "let's drop these particular lines, and open a new issue to get the acknowledgements right if that's needed".
