Editorial:
The repeated use of "transport protocol implementations" is hard to read here, somehow.  And it kinda makes me wish there was a solid definition of "capacity-seeking congestion controller" with an accepted acronym that we could use here, because that's what I think you really mean.  Maybe we could add a sub-section to sec-trans capturing this and cut this bullet to something like 1/4th-1/6th of its current length?

That's kind of brainstorming, not really making a firm suggestion, but I'm aiming to solve a problem here that this feels to me like too long an aside about too abstract a problem, or some such.
I like the concept here and contrasting the 2 separate competing bandwidth detection schemes in the following paragraph, that's a good insight and likely worth capturing, but I feel like the text in the first bullet is too hard to eat in one bite, and makes it so you can't swallow the whole concept at once.

That's an interesting suggestion about IOAM, but I'm leaning toward no.
I think from a mops point of view most of what you want from IOAM you can probably get with less dev work by monitoring interface stats, and for most operators if they try to pull on this thread it would be a wild goose chase they'll regret.  Maybe that'll change as that work develops, but probably if it does it'll be with a monitoring product or 2 that just operates at a different layer, so the media operators just consume the cool new stats and don't worry too much about how they got there.

Are there any papers we can reference here on what stats are important here?  I haven't really done much in this space, but my instinct is that if there's a good reference we can point to, outlining the useful stats to collect and good known ways to collect them seems worthwhile, but we should avoid making up as much as we possibly can.
(And regarding the first open issue about whether to mention protocols, I guess if we do wind up pointing to stats approaches, saying what contexts they can work in seems ok, otherwise less is more here I expect.  I don't think people need a list of transport protocols in this section if there's not something in particular we need to attach to them.)
I recently read this and liked it: https://www.compiralabs.com/ultimate-guide-congestion-control
@acbegen - I do like that paper. Are you thinking we should put it in the "further reading" section, or try to use it to make sure we haven't missed anything in our text, or something else?

@GrumpyOldTroll - that makes perfect sense, but I had to ask. 

It's also worth noting that I've taken out references to specific products in other sections when we at least had something to point at from an industry forum. Is there anything we could say, that isn't vendor-specific?

@GrumpyOldTroll, this is the current state of play in QLog: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/search/?name=quic-qlog&activedrafts=on.

If I write something that accurately describes that state of play, do you think that's OK? And if it's OK, is it sufficient?
And yes, I will add this to the reading list.

We talked about this on the call some, like "is there a set of stats we can recommend watching?" and it seems like there's some work in progress in that space but nothing nailed down (honorable mentions included https://github.com/cta-wave/common-media-server-data and https://www.streamingvideoalliance.org/project/video-quality-tags-vqt/).

The point mentioned about monitoring just the network latency in TCP was ok, and you can maybe do the same for just latency with the quic spin-bit without needing the stats reported from the endpoint with qlog, but it seems to me like a can of worms here to recommend this in-network monitoring, as opposed to client-reported video stats for instance.  And when we add in that this issue I think we called a nice-to-have, it's maybe better to keep the can closed...

That last point that I mentioned I liked is the one that's sort of covered already in section 4.5 (https://htmlpreview.github.io/?https://github.com/ietf-wg-mops/draft-ietf-mops-streaming-opcons/blob/gh-pages/draft-ietf-mops-streaming-opcons.html#name-bitrate-detection-challenge), namely that there's 2 control loops involved that are not always doing the same thing.

comments.author: acbegen
comments.body:
> > Some media content providers aim to achieve this level of latency for live media events. This introduces new challenges relative to less-restricted levels of latency requirements because this latency is the same scale as commonly observed end-to-end network latency variation (for example, due to effects such as bufferbloat, Wi-Fi error correction, or packet reordering). These effects can make it difficult to achieve this level of latency for the general case, and may require tradeoffs in relatively frequent user-visible media artifacts. However, for controlled environments or targeted networks that provide mitigations against such effects, this level of latency is potentially achievable with the right provisioning.
> 
> I like this text. I have thoughts.
> 
> * Do we need a reference for "bufferbloat"? We haven't used that term in the document yet, and I agree with using it here. I note [this relatively recent RFC used this reference for the term](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8033#ref-CoDel).

Yes, lets add it.

> * I agree with "the right provisioning", but for someone not skilled in the art, that may be like "and then a miracle occurs", and I suspect a lot of people still assume "the right provisioning" means something like "the right **bandwidth** provisioning", which isn't what we mean at all, is it? ISTM that we might (1) mention DSCP, (2) mention https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-tsvwg-nqb/ as something to be aware of.

Well, I really don't want to imply that right provisioning requires QoS or at least some DSCP marking. Yes, to many, the answer could be just providing enough bandwidth for others, it could be a bit more complicated. If you have seen my recent ANRW talk, I refer to the "QoS" as the first camp (slide 5) and many efforts to date simply failed in that aspect.

Paper: https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/3472305.3472886
Slides: https://irtf.org/anrw/2021/slides-111-anrw-sessd-manus-manum-lavat-media-clients-and-servers-cooperating-with-common-media-clientserver-data-00.pdf

reviews.author: SpencerDawkins
reviews.body:
> Some media content providers aim to achieve this level of latency for live media events. This introduces new challenges relative to less-restricted levels of latency requirements because this latency is the same scale as commonly observed end-to-end network latency variation (for example, due to effects such as bufferbloat, Wi-Fi error correction, or packet reordering). These effects can make it difficult to achieve this level of latency for the general case, and may require tradeoffs in relatively frequent user-visible media artifacts. However, for controlled environments or targeted networks that provide mitigations against such effects, this level of latency is potentially achievable with the right provisioning.

I like this text. I have thoughts. 

- Do we need a reference for "bufferbloat"? We haven't used that term in the document yet, and I agree with using it here. I note [this relatively recent RFC used this reference for the term](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8033#ref-CoDel). 
- I agree with "the right provisioning", but for someone not skilled in the art, that may be like "and then a miracle occurs", and I suspect a lot of people still assume "the right provisioning" means something like "the right **bandwidth** provisioning", which isn't what we mean at all, is it? ISTM that we might (1) mention DSCP, (2) mention https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-tsvwg-nqb/ as something to be aware of.
